stream_context.summary: Kaze continues building the Oil/Soap Blargg “black boss” fight, focusing on flee behavior, damage feedback (primitive-color flashing), and overall arena presentation. The stream also surfaces a major N64 constraint: the ROM is nearing the 64MB limit largely due to streamed music, forcing upcoming tradeoffs in audio format and course planning. Personal update: Kaze and Zeina bought a house and are preparing to move, shaping near-term workflow (more off-stream work, big push on a day off).
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a concrete production constraint (ROM size dominated by streamed music) that will affect remaining course content, while also showing boss-fight iteration (mechanics + readability) and real-life schedule changes (house move) that impact development cadence.

findings.summary: The Oil/Soap Blargg boss fight structure is clarified: Blargg loops attacks (including wave attacks), occasional soap pieces drop/appear, and soap is the intended tool to damage him; the player repeats the damage phase multiple times (roughly three) rather than it being a final phase.

Kaze implements/iterates flee behavior: when Mario is on the soap/attacking, Blargg should run away in a circular path in the direction farthest from Mario (using Mario’s angle) and become more panicked/animated under pressure.

Damage feedback is being implemented via N64 combiner/primitive-color flashing (prim brightness/color). Kaze runs into issues where the glow persists and state doesn’t reliably reset, and he experiments with color choice (blue vs orange/green) for readability.

Kaze avoids adding new per-object variables because expanding the global object struct would cost 4 bytes for every object in memory; instead he looks for unused existing fields (e.g., health) to repurpose for boss-specific state (like counting hits before a teleport/behavior change).
findings.quote: Because that would expand the object struct and we would lose four bytes for every object in the entire world.

findings.summary: Fast64 workflow constraints surface: switch bones are described as unreliable (“switch bones suck”), and Fast64 appears to reset animation/channel values to zero in a frustrating way. There’s also confusion/argument over whether GeoASM nodes can have children (engine vs tool restrictions).

To communicate soap spawning diegetically, Kaze considers showing “strike workers” trapped in visible jail cells around the arena; a specific janitor Koopa (previously established in the hub/overworld) would be the one not on strike and would throw sparkling soap bars into the arena. Kaze prefers this over button prompts or intrusive text.

Arena theming is reconsidered: the original “inside an oil barrel” look is not working visually (repetition/ugly walls/cages). New direction: a gated-off oil warehouse/junkyard vibe—potentially a warehouse built into a cave—half metal/half rock, with a rectangular/sinking oil surface while keeping the grill/platform mechanic.

ROM budget is becoming a hard constraint: the build is ~45.9MB already, and sound data is ~35.6MB. Kaze estimates the project is slightly over budget if scaled to 15 courses, meaning upcoming courses may need fewer streamed tracks (possibly Course 12 without a streamed song) and/or conversions to sequenced music (with quality and performance tradeoffs).
findings.quote: This is 35.6 megabytes of just music… two-thirds of the ROM is just music.

findings.summary: Kaze notes a major monthly revenue spike on YouTube (income up ~100% while views rose ~30% and watch time ~50%), speculating YouTube’s anti–ad blocker behavior may be increasing ad views. He reiterates he left Twitch due to excessive ads.

Kaze and Zeina bought a house and expect to move on the 23rd. He anticipates working from a basement/dungeon-like room with little sunlight and plans a productivity push on an upcoming day off (Monday), likely finishing the boss off-stream.

biobak.summary: Biobak gives animation/readability feedback: add stronger “in pain” cues while Mario is on Blargg (shake, faster animation), and add particles when the soap hits to reinforce the damage event.
Biobak asks detailed questions about N64 combiner math (primitive vs texture blending) to understand how to achieve the flashing/glow effect without washing out colors.

Biobak suggests fight-balancing tweaks (soap depleting faster; consider risk management around returning to safe platforms) and flags that damage feedback localized only near the mouth may be invisible from the typical camera angle (often behind Blargg).

badub.summary: Kaze previews a new Badub-made track for the “boombox koopas,” calling it very good—indicating ongoing bespoke music delivery during active level/boss development.

findings.summary: Lilaa engages on Fast64/GeoASM setup details and is directly referenced when Kaze complains about Fast64 animation value resets and tooling friction, implying Lilaa is a frequent point of contact for tool/pipeline pain points.

Suggests a mechanic where the soap/“block” could grow again if the player waits while Blargg moves through oil, but Kaze pushes back because he doesn’t want to widen the skill gap between weaker and stronger players.

key_stories.title: Designing the Oil/Soap Blargg fight around readable phases
key_stories.summary: Kaze shows the boss’s flee behavior and discusses the intended structure: repeated attack cycles with waves, intermittent soap spawns, and a distinct damage phase when Mario uses the soap to hit Blargg. He iterates animation and feedback (panic, shaking, damage flashing) to ensure players understand when they’re making progress.
key_stories.challenge: Making the fight readable and fun: players must infer that soap is the key, understand when Blargg is vulnerable, and experience fair risk/reward (soap depletion, platform safety).
key_stories.process: Implements movement logic based on Mario’s angle/distance; adjusts speed scaling with damage; experiments with animation speed/shake; plans particles and color-flash feedback; debates whether returning to platforms should be allowed as a deliberate risk-management option.
key_stories.outcome: Core flee behavior and the concept of multi-cycle damage phases are in place, but Kaze still needs to implement respawn/teleport logic, particle feedback, platform/grill behavior, and finalize damage rules and timings.

key_stories.title: Hitting the 64MB wall: streamed music dominates the ROM
key_stories.summary: Kaze reveals the ROM is already ~45.9MB with ~35.6MB in sound data, meaning music is consuming roughly two-thirds of the budget. With 15 courses planned, he expects to exceed the limit unless audio decisions change.
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining high-quality music on real N64 constraints: streamed audio can’t be easily compressed and must be read from ROM, but converting to sequenced music risks lower quality and higher CPU/performance costs.
key_stories.process: Kaze estimates budget by scaling current course count to the final 15-course plan; considers reducing streamed tracks, selectively converting some songs to sequenced formats, or mono (which he dislikes). He notes he may be able to free ~1–2MB without quality loss through cleanup, but the main lever is music format choice.
key_stories.outcome: A concrete production constraint is now active: upcoming courses may ship without streamed music, and audio pipeline choices will shape both performance and presentation for the rest of the project.
key_stories.key_quote: We probably have to go to course 12 without a streamed song.

key_stories.title: Real-life schedule shift: moving into a new house
key_stories.summary: Kaze mentions he and Zeina bought a house and plan to move soon, joking he’ll be working from a windowless “dungeon.” He expects to finish much of the boss off-stream and use a day off to push progress.
key_stories.challenge: Keeping momentum during a major life transition that disrupts routine and workspace setup.
key_stories.process: Plans to shift complex work off-stream, bank progress during free time (day off Monday), and continue iterating between streams while setting up the new home/work area.
key_stories.outcome: Near-term cadence likely changes: more off-stream progress and potentially irregular stream scheduling around the move date.

open_questions.topic: Audio/ROM budget strategy for the remaining 4 courses
open_questions.context: Kaze reports the ROM is ~45.9MB and sound data alone is ~35.6MB, implying the project could exceed 64MB by the time 15 courses are included. He suggests limiting streamed music and possibly converting some tracks to sequenced formats, with performance/quality downsides.
questions: Which specific courses/tracks are currently streamed vs sequenced, and which ones are candidates to convert (or drop) to stay under 64MB?
What quality bar is ‘acceptable’ for sequenced conversions, and who will do the conversion work (Badub, ZeroVolt, Kaze)?
Are there engine-level options being considered (e.g., looping streamed stems, shared repeating segments) and what are the technical blockers on N64?
Will the 64MB cap be treated as non-negotiable for real hardware/flashcarts, or is there any contingency plan (e.g., separate builds, expanded ROM, optional packs)?

open_questions.topic: How Blargg’s disappear-and-reappear behavior will be triggered and tuned
open_questions.context: Kaze says implementing the trigger for Blargg fleeing/disappearing and respawning elsewhere is something he’s struggled with off-stream; it’s still not clearly designed at the state-machine level.
questions: What exact conditions should trigger the disappear/respawn (time since last hit, number of hits, player position, soap depletion, health thresholds)?
Will the respawn location be random, ‘farthest from Mario,’ or tied to specific arena points to avoid unfair outcomes?
How will you telegraph the disappear/respawn to the player (sound cue, particles, camera behavior) without breaking flow?

open_questions.topic: Diegetic soap delivery: strike workers/janitor cages implementation
open_questions.context: Kaze prefers a story-driven, in-world solution over UI prompts: show trapped workers in jail cells, with a janitor Koopa throwing sparkling soap bars into the arena. This is meant to make the mechanic self-explanatory.
questions: Where did the ‘strike workers’ premise originate in the project’s story, and how explicitly should the game explain it vs leaving it as environmental storytelling?
How will the camera framing guarantee players notice the cages/janitor and track the soap’s trajectory in a fast fight?
Will the janitor always throw to safe platforms (random grill targeting) or can soap land in hazards, and what fairness rules prevent unwinnable RNG?

open_questions.topic: Final arena art direction: oil barrel vs junkyard/warehouse-in-cave
open_questions.context: Kaze strongly dislikes the current look (repetitive walls, cages) and begins pivoting toward a gated-off oil warehouse/junkyard theme, possibly built into a cave with metal below and rock above, and a rectangular/sinking oil surface.
questions: What is the final narrative/location concept for this boss arena (who built it, why is it oil-filled, how does it connect to the level/world)?
What are the non-negotiable gameplay constraints driving the geometry (preventing jumps out, sightlines, platform layout), and how do they shape the art?
Who will own the rework tasks (modeling, textures, skybox), and what’s the timeline risk if the theming keeps changing?

open_questions.topic: N64 combiner/primitive flash pipeline and tooling pain (Fast64)
open_questions.context: Kaze implements damage flashing via primitive color but hits issues with reset behavior and washed-out color, plus Fast64 frustrations (animation channels resetting, switch bones).
questions: What is the final planned implementation for the damage flash (combiner equation, where it’s applied in the hierarchy, how it resets reliably)?
Are Fast64 limitations forcing design compromises (e.g., avoiding certain rigging/geo setups), and are there plans to patch tools or change the pipeline?
What debugging approach do you use when visual artifacts appear on real hardware vs emulator (and which hardware targets are you prioritizing)?
